captions.text:
JAMES GRIME: We're going
to break a rule.

We're break one of the
rules of Numberphile.

We're talking about something
that isn't a number.

We're going to talk
about infinity.
So infinity.

Now like I said, infinity
is not a number.
It's a idea.
It's a concept.

It's the idea of being endless,
of going on forever.

I think everyone's familiar
with the idea of
infinity, even kids.

You start counting
1, 2, 3, 4, 5--

you might be five years old, but
already you're thinking,

what's the biggest number
I can think of.
And you go, oooh, it's 20.

You get a bit older, and you
go, maybe it's a million.

It never ends, does it? 'Cause
you can keep adding 1.

So that's the idea
of infinity.
The numbers go on forever.

But I'm going to tell you one
of the more surprising facts
about infinity.

There are different
kinds of infinity.

Some infinities are bigger
than others.
Let's have a look.

The first type of infinity
is called countable.

And I don't like the
name countable.

And Brady gave me a little
bit of a hmm, just then.

Because if you're talking about
infinity, you can't
count infinity, can you?
Because it goes on forever.
I think it's a terrible name.
I prefer to call it listable.
Can we list these numbers?
All right.

Let's do these simple
numbers, 1, 2, 3--

BRADY HARAN: You're not gonna do
all of them, are you James?
JAMES GRIME: 4.
How long have we got?

BRADY HARAN: (LAUGHING)
10 minutes.
JAMES GRIME: Right.

so you can list the
whole numbers.
So this is called countable.
Listable, I prefer.
What about the integers?
All the integers.

That's all the negative
numbers as well.
So there's 0.
Let's have that.

But there's 1 and minus 1,
there's 2 and minus 2, there's
3, and minus 3.

Now, that is an infinity
as well.

And in some sense, it's twice as
big, because there seems to
be twice as many numbers.
But it is infinity as well.

They're both infinity,
and they're both the
same type of infinity.
They both can be listed.

Perhaps more surprisingly,
the fractions can
be listed as well.

But you have to be a bit
clever about this.

Let's try and list
the fractions.

I'm going to write
out a rectangle.
1 divided by 1.
That's a fraction.
[INAUDIBLE].

Let's have 1 divided by
2, 1/3, 1/4, 1/7--
OK, that goes on.

Let's do the next row and
have two at the top.
Let's do the next one.

That goes on and we
can keep going.

So here, I've made some sort of
an infinite rectangle array
of fractions.

Now if I want to make it a list
like this, though, If I

went row by row, you're going
to have a problem.

If you go row by
row, I'll go--
I'll keep going forever.

And I'm never going to
reach the second row.
I can't list them.
Not that way.
You can't list them that way.

You'll never reach
the second row.
This is how you list them.

Slightly more clever
than that.
You take the diagonal lines.

Now, I can guarantee that every
fraction will appear on
one of those diagonal lines.

And you list them diagonal
by diagonal.
So that's the first diagonal.

Then you list the second
diagonal-- there it is.

Then you list the third
diagonal, then you take the

fourth diagonal,
and the fifth.

So eventually, you are going
to do this every fraction.

Every faction appears on
a diagonal, and you're
going to list them.

Now, if you take all
the numbers, right?
That's the whole number line.
Let's try that.
Look, I'm going to draw it.

It's a continuous
line of numbers.
These are all your decimals.

You've got 0 there in the
middle, and you'll
go 1 and 2 and 3.
But it has a 1/3.

It will contain pi,
and e, and all the
irrational numbers as well.
Can you list them?
How do you list them?
0 to start with, and then 1?
But hang on.
We've missed a half.
So we put in the half.

Hang on, we've missed
the quarter.
We put in the quarter.
But we've missed 0.237--

so how do you list
the real numbers?
It turns out you can't.

In fact, rather remarkably, I
can show you that we can't

list them, even though were
talking about something so
complicated as infinity.
BRADY HARAN: Do it, man!
JAMES GRIME: We need paper.

BRADY HARAN: We need an
infinite amount of
paper here, I think.

JAMES GRIME: (LAUGHING)
It's a big topic.

Imagine we could list all
the decimals, right?
We can't, actually.
But pretend we can.
What sort of--
what would it look like?

We'll start with all the
0-point decimals.
Let's pick some decimals.
dot dot dot dot dot.
Let's pick the next one.

Let's say the next
one is 0.221--.

Next one, let's do
0.31111129--.

And let's take another
one, here.

Now I'm going to
make a number.

This is the number I'm
going to make.

I'm going to take the
diagonals here.

I'm going to take this number
and this number and this

number and this number
and this number.

And I am going to
write that down.

So what's that number
I've made?

something, something,
something.
Now this is my rule.

I'm going to make a whole new
number from that one.

This is the number I'm
going to make.

If it has a 1, I'm going
to change it to a 2.

And if it has a 2 or anything
else, I will change it to a 1.
So let's try that.

So I'm going to turn
this into--
0-point.

So if it has a 1, I'm going
to turn it into a 2.

If it's anything else, I'm going
to turn it into a 1.
So that will be a 1.

I'm going to change
1 here into a 2.

I'm going to change
that one into a 1.

I'm going to change that one
into a 2-- that was my rule.
And I'll make something new.

That does not appear
on the list.

That number is completely
different from anything else

on the list, because it's not
the first number, because it's
different in the first place.

It's not the second number,
because it's different in
second place.

It's not the third number,
because it's different in the
third place.

It's not the fourth number
because it's different in the
fourth place.

It's not the fifth number,
because it's different in the
fifth place.

You've made a number that's
not on that list.

And so you can't list all the
decimals, in which case it is
uncountable.
It is unlistable.

And that means it's a whole
new type of infinity.
A bigger type of infinity.

BRADY HARAN: Surely we could,
James, because all we've got

to do is keep doing your game
and making them and adding
them to the list.

And if we keep doing that, won't
we get there eventually?

JAMES GRIME: But you could then
create another number
that won't be on that list.

And so the guy who came up with
is a German mathematician
called Cantor.

Cantor lived 'round about the
turn of the 20th century.
He was ridiculed for this.

For this idea that there were
different types of infinity,
he was called a charlatan.

And he was called-- it was
nonsense, it was called.

And poor old Cantor was treated
really badly by his

contemporaries, and he spent a
lot of his later life in and

out of mental institutions,
where he died, in the end.

Near the end of his life,
it was recognized.
It was true.
It was recognized.

And he had all the recognition
that he deserved.

BRADY HARAN: And now he's
on Numberphile.

JAMES GRIME: And now he's on
Numberphile, the greatest
accolade of all.
Georg Cantor.

title: Infinity is bigger than you think - Numberphile

comments.author: TheCoolDood112358

comments.text:
Haha, I thought the title was a play on words. For example, if you think of 
a number, infinity is bigger than what you thought. Think of a bigger 
number. Infinity is still bigger than what you thought. Think of an even 
bigger number, and infinity is still bigger. And so on and so on. 
Therefore, infinity is bigger than you think.﻿
comments.author: Zack Martin

comments.text:
When I read mathematics at university I always had reservations about the 
term 'countable', so I really like your use of 'list'. However, it has 
always bothered me that we refer to some infinities as 'bigger' than 
others. I prefer the word 'denser'. For example, {-3, -2, -1, 0, 1, 2, 3} 
contains seven elements (regardless of what we choose to label them) that 
can be counted with the first seven natural numbers (1 above -3, 2 above -2 
and so on up to 7 above 3). Perhaps a clearer example is to consider all 
rational numbers between 0 and 1, an infinite number. Yet, the distance 
between 0 and 1 is one for natural numbers and also for rationals (or any 
other). The only difference being that the space between 0 and 1 is empty 
for natural numbers but infinitely dense for the rationals. Your comments, 
please... and a thoroughly 'dense' "thank you" for the excellent videos!﻿

comments.author: Lance Fartzalot

comments.text:
So infinity is a concept, I get that, but this seems wrong, using 
irrational numbers as a part of an explanation for a concept as if it's a 
number, which it's not. Technically speaking infinity can't be reached, but 
can't it be... viewed? Like, continuously halving the number one will never 
get you to 0, but it will get you close. So wouldn't that also occur if you 
simply multiplied? By two, by three, by a billion, whatever. Eventually you 
would get a number so immense, it would seem to be infinity. Then you could 
multiply it by itself. Exponentials. You would always get a bigger number, 
like how you would get a smaller one by dividing, but the difference would 
eventually be so miniscule as to seem non-existent. Couldn't you, in 
theory, get close to infinity?﻿

comments.author: XXLGameplay

comments.text:
The idea most people have about infinity is that it goes on forever, so I 
understand your point of view, but in mathematics you learn many properties 
about infinity.

Here are more formal definitions so you can get a taste of what's really 
going on:

A set (which is any collection of objects, like the set of all fractions) 
is called "countably infinite" if there exists a bijection between that set 
and the set of all positive integers.

A bijection is a function between sets: it takes an element of the first 
set and tells you where in the second set that element is mapped to. 
Additionally, a bijection is one-to-one, which means each element in the 
first set is mapped to a unique element in the second set, and it's also 
onto, which means that for every element in the second set, there's an 
element in the first set which maps to it.

If a set is infinite but there does not exist a bijection between it and 
the positive integers, then that set is uncountably infinite.

Now, this is all very abstract and requires a lot of math education to 
understand, but that's what's going on behind the scenes.
comments.author: Matt L

comments.text: no it is infinite so that means it can't get bigger than it
comments.author: XXLGameplay

comments.text:
+XXLGameplay The reason this explanation might seem a little fuzzy is 
because there's a lot of abstract math going on behind the scenes which 
wasn't talked about in this video because it's too advanced for the video. 
It is actually true that "uncountable infinities" are "bigger" than 
"countable infinities" for reason which are rigorous but again, require 
math beyond the scope of this video to explain.


It's not an easy thing to see intuitively, but here's one way to see it: 
the number of whole numbers is a "smaller" infinity than the number of real 
numbers. What this essentially means is that for every single whole number, 
there are an infinite amount of real numbers (like there are an infinite 
number of real numbers between 1`and 2). So, when you think about the 
infinite number of whole numbers, you get this massive, even larger 
infinity of real numbers.

comments.text:
I dont get it quite...
With the whole numbers, you can always +1 and get the next one in the list 
of whole numbers. That list is never going to be complete, but you can list 
them.

With the decimals, you apparently can't, because you can always find a 
number that is not in the list. But if you find one of those numbers that 
is not in the list, you can add it to the list. If you keep searching for 
numbers that are not in the list, you can keep adding them to that list. 
How is that so different from the list you're creating with the whole 
numbers?

Or does the difference lie in the fact that every whole number you create 
by adding 1 to the previous, is already on the list of the whole numbers, 
you just didnt write it yet. But with the decimals, you keep finding 
decimal numbers that do not belong in the list just yet?

I'm confused﻿

comments.text:
+Bas Vrebosch 
*With the whole numbers, you can always +1 and get the next one in the list 
of whole numbers. That list is never going to be complete, but you can list 
them.*
It is called listable because if you have a peice of paper that is 
infinitely long and infinite time you can write them all down because you 
can write it like an ordinary list.


*With the decimals, you apparently can't, because you can always find a 
number that is not in the list. But if you find one of those numbers that 
is not in the list, you can add it to the list. If you keep searching for 
numbers that are not in the list, you can keep adding them to that list. 
How is that so different from the list you're creating with the whole 
numbers?*
Because no matter hwo many you add to the list you'll have infinitely many 
you've missed.

comments.text:
Here is a mindblowing fact for you: No one number has an exact previous 
number or an exact number after. For example 3 can not have a previous 
number because the decimals never end. 2.999... cannot be one either 
because you cannot put a number bettween 3 and 2.999... so 2.999... is 3 
written in a different way. Also 3 does not have a number after it because 
3.000... continues to infinity and as a result you can not put 1 nowhere.﻿

comments.text:
No. Not according to relativity theory. And yes, here is the biggest 
problem in modern psysics: how to combine quantum physics (of which quantum 
foam/vacuum/vacuum enery is a part) and general relativity (where vacuum is 
only the empty space between objects). There is no definte ansver; which 
imply that nobody can say that "the universe is infinite". And of course we 
cannot *yet* say that the universi is not infinite, either. So this is in 
any way an argument against what I wrote about "there is only order, 
relations and geometry in the world, and no numbers", as an argument 
against number.based maths.

comments.text:
+Dimitris Bekiaris There is something irrational in the use of numbers. 
After what I know, Gödel's incompleteness theorem is only valid when 
counting with numbers; pure logical mathematic systems can be complete, but 
are also very hard to do advanced maths with. In our reality we only have 
order, logic, relations, proportions and geometry -- numbers is a 
construction we use as a help, and they only confuse us when they lead us 
to incomprehensible things like infinity (which probably not exist in 
reality, either).

comments.author: lazer gorrillas

comments.text:
Yeah, I know that every nonempty open interval of the real numbers is 
uncountably infinite while the integers are countably infinite. I worded 
that pooly; what I meant was that you've matched every integer to real 
numbers between -1 and 1, but I didn't mean that you've used every real 
number between -1 and 1.
comments.author: Matt L

comments.text:
+Matt L You can't match up the real numbers between 0 and 1 with the 
integers.
comments.author: TimofAwsome

comments.text:
+lazer gorrillas The reason why you can't do that is simple:
There are numbers such as pi or sqrt(2) which have an infinite amount of 
digits. So to match these numbers with natural numbers would require a 
natural number with an infinite amount of digits. However these digits 
would be before and not after the comma, making the number infinitely big. 
But infinity is not an element of the natural numbers. Therefore numbers 
such as pi do not have a match within the natural numbers.
comments.author: DarkSt3ve

comments.text:
+lazer gorrillas That's true, for any decimal between 0 and 1, such as 
.249374..., you can match it up with an integer. In this way, for every 
positive integer, there exists a real number between 0 and 1 which matches 
to it like this. 

However, after you've done this, you've in a sense "used up" all of the 
integers, but you've only used real numbers between 0 and 1. The integer 
249374... matches up to 0.249374..., but doesn't it also match up to 
1.249374...? And 2.249374..., and 3.249374, and 4.249374, and so on. This 
isn't a proof, but hopefully this example convinces you that there are 
"more" real numbers than integers.

comments.text:
+Simon Banks Actually, you can... If you have an "algorithm" that tells you 
which number you put in your list just by knowing the previous one, you can 
list them.What James was trying to say is "something countable is something 
finite". Because if you can count them, it means that, after a while, you 
can say "I counted how many apples there are" so that means, there is a 
finite number of apples.
To speak a bit more about listability, you can say that positive integers 
are listable because you can follow this algorithm:
-The first number on the list is 1
-If you know the (k)th number, then the (k+1)th number will be 1 + (k)th 
number.
And as James said, you can't do that with real numbers

comments.author: Simple1DEA

comments.text:
+Simple1DEA Yeah, this is a tough concept. There are rigorous proofs of 
these things that use crazy math, but I'll try to explain it without that 
stuff (just so you know that this has been rigorously defined).

Let's say you were trying to match each integer with a real number in a 
one-to-one fashion. Given an integer, say 438, you could match it with the 
real number 0.438. Similarly, you could match the integer -1024 to the real 
number -0.1024. (And you could match 4380 to 0.0438, 43800 to 0.00438, etc.)


I think it's pretty clear that, using this method of matching, if you take 
any integer, no matter how large, there exists a real number between -1 and 
1 which you can match it to. It should also be clear that no two integers 
match to the same real number. 


So, consider the integer 31. You could match it to 0.31. But then, couldn't 
it also match to 1.31? And 2.31? And 3.31, 4.31, 5.31, .......? You've 
"used up" all of the integers and matched "all" of them to real numbers 
between -1 and 1. But then you have all the real numbers less than -1 and 
greater than 1 you haven't taken into account.


This obviously isn't a proof, but hopefully it convinces you that there are 
"more" real numbers than integers. Formally, we say the real numbers are 
uncountably infinite while the integers are countably infinite, like was 
described in the video.


The real numbers are "dense." Dense is a mathematical term, but you can see 
why it's called that; there are just so many real numbers that the number 
line is dense with numbers. If you list all of the integers on the number 
line you have tons of gaps everywhere but if you list all the real numbers 
there are no gaps. For example, there is no smallest (in terms of absolute 
value) real number. If you take any super small real number, like 
0.00000000.....00001, you can always keep dividing by 2 indefinitely to get 
a smaller real number. This is another property of the real numbers that 
shows that there are just "so many" of them.
comments.author: Matt L

comments.text:
When I was learning about lines, rays, line segments, etc in the 5th grade 
I realized that there was something going on; a line had an infinite number 
of points with no beginning and end. A ray also had an infinite number of 
points, no end, but it had a beginning. A line segment had an infinite 
number of points but had a beginning and end. Then it started to go the 
other way; a plain was made of an infinite number of lines, an infinite 
number of points, no beginning or end in two dimensions. Space was the same 
in three dimensions. Then geometric shapes were like line segments in two 
or three dimensions. I was pretty excited to realize that various geometric 
objects had varying degrees of infinity. Was even more excited when it 
occurred to me that this applied to numbers too. I was immensely 
disappointed when not only did my teacher and classmates share my 
excitement but they did not even get it.  Reactions ranged from not getting 
what I was saying to mocking to denial. I raised it in several other math 
and science classes over the years with no better results. It was not until 
my early 20's when I read Asimov On Numbers that I found someone else who 
got it. Of course, it was a bit disappointing to find out that someone beat 
me to it some decades before I was born, but at least I was spared the 
mental institutions.....﻿
comments.author: 1smallstep

comments.text:
+1smallstep Except a line segment, ray, line (R), plane (R^2), and space 
(R^3) all have the same number of elements.

comments.text:
There's a fun topic related to this. In D&D (before 4th edition at least) 
there are planes, the places where gods and such live. These planes are 
infinitely large.

But some of those planes have layers - connected to a single whole, but 
each layer itself is infinite. the two most interesting ones are the evil 
ones - Baator and the Abyss. Baator has 9 layers, each layer infinitely 
vast. The Abyss has infinite layers, each layer infinitely vast.

The inhabitants of these planes are in constant war, attempting to destroy 
each other, despite it being literally impossible to actually make any 
meaningful progress because both of them have infinite amounts of area. 
This war has been going on for billions of years, and many of the 
inhabitants are fully aware of how ridiculous it is.

The Abyss has more inhabitants, but it gets to the point where it honestly 
doesnt matter. Still, it keeps the evil demons and devils occupied. It 
would be bad if their war stopped and they decided to work together against 
other people. Fortunately, it can't stop.﻿

Lol this makes no sense. It's like saying a pound of feathers is heavier 
than a pound of bricks. Infinity is not a thing. It describes the never 
ending or unlimited quality of a thing. There is no such thing as "an 
infinity". Counting 1, 2, 3, is simply making a different list of numbers 
than counting 0.1, 0.2, 0.3... And moreover, there are the same quantity of 
numbers in an infinite list of decimals as there are in an infinite list of 
whole numbers...infinite. Just because there are more numbers listed 
between...say 1-100... does not make an infinite list of decimals bigger 
than an infinite list of whole numbers. By this guy's logic, a pound of 
bricks is not only heavier, but it is a different pound, than a pound of 
feathers, because there are more molecules per unit of space in bricks than 
feathers.﻿
comments.author: El Hombre Mo

comments.text:
Why is the unlistable infinity considered bigger than the listable 
infinity? Since between any two distinct reals there is at least one 
rational (an infinite number of rationals in fact) how can the number of 
reals be bigger than the number of rationals? 

Consider the first number on your list in your Cantor proof 
example, 0.1213712912…. You haven't really specified a number there, you 
have just written down the initial decimal expansion of some number that is 
presumably specified elsewhere. If there is really a list, then for each 
number on the list, there will somewhere need to be some finite sequence of 
mathematical symbols that actually refers to the specific number.

Each of these sequences of symbols will refer to a number that has a 
decimal expansion that begins with a sequence of digits, so your proof is 
valid, but the actual specification of the number cannot be an infinite 
sequence of mathematical symbols or a partial decimal expansion. It has to 
be something with a specification of finite length that refers to a 
specific number, something like e/pi or sqrt(3).

But the set of possible finite sequences of mathematical symbols is 
listable. You can start with all possible symbol sequences of length 1, 
length 2, and so on. This list will contain every real number that it is 
possible to mention, because every possible specification will appear 
somewhere on the list.

This list will thus include all of the numbers you can put on any specific 
Cantor list, and it will also contain the number you constructed that 
cannot be on that Cantor list. It doesn't violate the Cantor proof because 
it also includes other sequences of mathematical symbols that don't refer 
to numbers (they could even be meaningless sequences of symbols). Your 
proof is about lists that contain only numbers, my list avoids your proof 
because it contains other things in addition to all the numbers that can be 
specified.

So, although I agree that the real numbers are not listable, it doesn't 
appear to be because there are too many to list. The Cantor proof shows 
that the set of reals that can be mentioned is not a listable set, but a 
set that includes all those reals and more is listable. So the unlistable 
set of reals that can go on a Cantor list (i.e. that can be specified) is 
not larger than the set of integers.

Of course, in some sense it appears that there are real numbers that won't 
appear on my list either, but as there is no way to refer to any of them it 
is not entirely clear to me what it means to say that such numbers exist.

I'm interested in the idea that there might exist numbers that cannot be 
specified. I like to call them "mystical numbers". You can believe in them, 
and perhaps even prove in some abstract sense that they must exist, but 
cannot point to any of them, cannot experience them. They are, in that 
sense, beyond conception. Since Mathematics is entirely symbolic, what does 
it mean to say that such numbers exist in Mathematics when there is no 
symbolic expression that specifically represents any of them?﻿
